'''Candy Palmater''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] comedian and broadcaster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metronews.ca/halifax/local/article/89130|title=Comedians celebrate pride with laughter|last=Lisk|first=Dean|date=July 25, 2008|publisher=Metro.news|access-date=March 29, 2010}}</ref> She was the creator and writer of her own national TV show for [[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|APTN]], ''The Candy Show'',<ref name=xtra>Angelina Chapin, [http://www.xtra.ca/public/National/Sweet_hardearned_success_for_Candy_Palmater-4654.aspx Sweet, hard-earned success for Candy Palmater]. ''[[Xtra!]]'', April 21, 2008.</ref> and hosted the daily interview series ''The Candy Palmater Show'' on [[CBC Radio One]] in summer 2016.<ref name="cbcradio">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/candy-palmater-show-out-in-the-open-1.3583908 "CBC Radio to debut Out in the Open, The Candy Palmater Show"]. [[CBC News]], May 16, 2016.</ref>
Palmater was born in 1968 in [[Point La Nim, New Brunswick|Point La Nim]], [[New Brunswick]],<ref>[http://www.dailyxtra.com/ottawa/arts-and-entertainment/candy-palmaters-got-ambition-burn-8071 "Candy Palmater's got ambition to burn"]. ''[[Xtra!]]'', October 28, 2008.</ref> and grew up the youngest of seven children. She attended Dalhousie Regional High School, where she was active in sports.<ref name="danielnpaul.com">Daniel N. Paul, [http://www.danielnpaul.com/Col/1999/AttitudeOfYoungGivesHopeForNon-RacistFuture.html "Attitude of young gives hope for non-racist future"]. ''Halifax Herald'', July 23, 1999.</ref> She currently resides in [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia]].
== Education ==
After high school, she attended Fredericton's [[St. Thomas University (New Brunswick)|St. Thomas University]] and then completed a legal secretary's course at Maritime Business College.<ref name="danielnpaul.com"/>
She was inspired by the legal failures of [[Donald Marshall Jr.]] and in 1996, she went to Dalhousie University, Halifax Nova Scotia, to study Law at Schulich School of Law, where she graduated in 1999 as the valedictorian of her class. She was the first Aboriginal law student in Canada to be valedictorian of her graduating class, and was president of the Dalhousie Aboriginal Law Students Association.
She got a job with the now defunct Law firm [[Patterson Palmer Hunt Murphy]], but soon realized she didn’t want to practice corporate law,<ref name=xtra /> and subsequently left her job and began working for the [[Nova Scotia Department of Education]].
==Career==
She was a regular contributor to [[CBC Radio]]'s ''[[Definitely Not the Opera]]'' and an interim host of ''[[Q (radio show)|Q]]'', and was a columnist for the now defunct Halifax newspaper ''[[The Daily News (Halifax)|The Daily News]]'', where she wrote a series for [[Mi’kmaq History Month]].
[[CBC Newsworld]] did a one-hour documentary on Palmater titled ''The Candy Show''. It was produced and directed by Mary Munson in Halifax. The executive producer was Renée Pellerin.
[[File:Candy on set of Season 3 - The Candy Show.jpg|thumb|right|Season 3 The Candy Show]]
''The Candy Show'' is also the title of a regular comedy series which airs on [[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|APTN]]. Palmater is also a regular performer on the [[comedy club]] circuit in Canada, as well as a frequent host of entertainment galas and events.
Palmater produced her first film, ''Building Legends: The Mi'Kmaq Canoe Project'', in 2011.
As an actor, she has had roles in the television series ''[[Forgive Me (TV series)|Forgive Me]]'', ''[[Sex & Violence (TV series)|Sex & Violence]]'', and ''[[Trailer Park Boys]]''.
Her daily CBC Radio summer series ''The Candy Palmater Show'' debuted on May 30, 2016.<ref name=cbcradio/> Following the end of that show's run, she did another stint as guest host of ''Q'' for several weeks in September and October, between the departure of [[Shad (rapper)|Shad]] and the debut of permanent new host [[Tom Power (musician)|Tom Power]]. In 2017 she was a panelist on ''[[Canada Reads]]'', advocating for [[Katherena Vermette]]'s novel ''The Break''.
==Awards== She was nominated for an [[East Coast Music Award]] for Media Person of the Year in 2013. ''The Candy Show'' was also nominated for a [[Canadian Screen Award]] for Best Direction in a Variety or Comedy TV Series, for director Trevor Grant. For her work on the television series ''Forgive Me'', she was nominated for an ACTRA Award for Best Supporting Actress.
In 2017, Palmater was presented the Bonham Centre Award from The Mark S. Bonham Centre for Sexual Diversity Studies, University of Toronto, for her contributions to the advancement and education of issues around sexual identification.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.utoronto.ca/news/decolonizing-sexuality-u-t-recognizes-indigenous-educators-and-advocates-sexual-diversity|title=Decolonizing sexuality: U of T recognizes Indigenous educators and advocates for sexual diversity|author=|date=|website=University of Toronto News|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref>
